awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Integrating Casual Discovery and Feature Selection with Streaming Features
awd_abstract_narration:
With the advent of emerging massive datasets in image processing,
biology, finance, and so on, traditional data mining systems
face new challenges to induce knowledge and discover causal
relations in dynamic streaming feature environments, where new
features continuously stream in over time. These challenges include
(1) continuous growth of feature volumes over time, (2) a huge feature
space, even of unknown or infinite size, and (3) not all features
being available before learning begins. These challenges call for a
new learning paradigm with continuously increasing features. In this
project, we take the increasing feature volumes as streaming features,
and the corresponding learning problem is referred to as Online
Learning with Streaming Features (OLSF). Since existing online
learning efforts mostly deal with data with increasing observations
but fixed feature dimensions, OLSF provides a unique chance to unfold
and characterize pattern trends for dynamic systems with streaming
features.

This project aims to address two fundamental issues for OLSF: (1)
causal discovery with sequentially increasing feature dimensions; and
(2) causal relations for feature selection. We design novel methods
and algorithms for causal discovery in OLSF and establish formal connections
between casual discovery and feature selection by investigating the
mutual benefits between them in the context of online stream feature
learning.  To evaluate the proposed research, we conduct empirical
studies on a large body of benchmark datasets, as well as with a
domain-specific real-world case study in personalized news filtering
and summarization where the feature space changes over time.  The
new algorithms and techniques in this project will advance our ability
to discover knowledge from dynamic systems using streaming features
with bounded resources. The spectrum of the methods from the project
will not only enrich our knowledge and understanding of pattern
discovery and machine learning for dynamic systems, but also provide a
new view to capture and characterize dynamic systems from a streaming
feature perspective.

por.por_cntn:
As the tremendous data are generated daily in all domains, with varying features continuously streaming in over time, the traditional learning systems fail to work functionally due to encountering new challenges in such dynamic streaming features environments. It is in urgent calling for innovative solutions to address such potential challenges as real-time streaming in of data, unknown/infinite sized feature space, and unavailable features before learning. To that end, we formulate the corresponding problem as Online Learning with Streaming Features (OLSF) and develop a collection of solutions for handling different scenarios in dynamic streaming feature environments. 

 

There are a number of milestones and highlights from our investigation. We have considered the trapezoidal data streams, by assuming the feature amounts keep increasing over time with the incoming of new instances. Effective algorithms were designed to learn a classifier by keeping track of the cumulative sum of  squared gradients, the negative cumulative sum of gradients, maximum feature values occurred and the cumulative sum of occurrences of features. We then employed the scaled gradients to update their corresponding classifier weights. Our solution was demonstrated to be effective for handling the trapezoidal data, but it has limited applications. We then conducted research by taking into account the streaming data with arbitrarily varying feature spaces (named as OLVF). We dynamically projected the instance classifier and the training instance onto their shared feature subspace. After that, the classifier on the feature space predicts the projection confidence for a give feature space. Meanwhile, we followed the empirical risk minimization principle to update the instance classifier. Our proposed OLVF can indeed capture the feature variation in the streaming environments. But this solution requires to have the full labels while providing full labeling is time-consuming in real-world scenarios due to the huge amount of streaming data. As such, we continue to develop a new solution, named as Online Learning in Variable Feature Spaces under Incomplete Supervision (OVSIS), which can effectively handle the data streams living in a feature space being arbitrarily variable with labels rarely given. We first constructed a universal feature space containing a union of all features carried by previously arrived instances. Once a new instance carrying disparate features arrives, we projected those features to the universal space via reconstructing the features unobserved in this instance. To address the labels scarcity problem, an arrival instance will be labeled by the manifold structure in the universal space, done by measuring the geometry distances among this instance and all previously arrived contents, given that the contents located in the neighboring region should have similar labels. We carefully designed the objectives for universal space projection and the manifold structure regularizer, for jointly training once the labels are provided occasionally. This can correct the real-time classifier through minimizing the feature reconstruction error and discovering the optimal geometry position for data labeling simultaneously.

 

The outcome of this project provides new methodologies and technical solutions to enrich online learning in the dynamic streaming environments, which can benefit broader disciplines with emerging large volumes of streaming features. This project has supported multiple Ph.D. students working on their dissertations, and involved several undergraduate students’ participation into research, offering them the unique opportunity to conduct the cutting-edge research. Such an experience will benefit their life-long career in science and engineering.
